page.title: 10St.Mary's Church,Cilcain
page.content: The present building dates from the 14th century but a carved stone basin found on the site, thought to be the remains of a Norman font, suggests the existence of an earlier structure. The church is interesting in that it has two naves, only one now being used for services. The most impressive feature of the church is the 15th century hammer-beam roof, which has the large carved wooden figure of an angel at either end of the four main beams. The roof, regarded as one of the finest of its type in the country, was not made originally for this building but is reputed to have been brought here from Basingwerk Abbey, near Holywell, after the dissolution of the monastery. The church is still in regular use,but now the local vicar is responsible for a number of parishes and no longer lives in the village.
